repnme.cdata!: Latvia - Municipal Solid Waste Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Municipal Solid
            Waste Management Project for Latvia was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was substantial, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned
            from the project: The rivalry between the two
            municipalities, the Riga City and the Stopinu Pagasts, was
            an impediment during Project preparation, and unfortunately
            continued during the first years of implementation. The
            appointment of management team by Riga City Council, could
            have been done in a more efficient way. Additional
            difficulty in the starting phase of the project was caused
            by differences between Latvian and Swedish detailed design
            standards, because the engineering consultant prepared the
            drawings in accordance with the latter.

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Solid Waste Management and
            Landfill Gas Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Solid Waste Management
            Project in Latvia demonstrates modern, self-sustaining
            management of municipal solid waste through maximum
            collection of generated methane, thereby reducing greenhouse
            gas emissions and creating a revenue stream to cover capital
            and operational costs of the improved landfill. The
            project's components 1) remediate the existing site to
            meet environmental requirements in regard to leachate
            treatment and to avoid future groundwater contamination, 2)
            provide technical and operational improvements to meet
            western sanitary landfill standards, and arrangements for
            improving the separation of recyclable materials; 3)
            establish energy cells for enhanced degradation of easily
            biodegradable waste, landfill collection, and electricity
            generation; and 4) provide technical and managerial
            assistance through twinning arrangements.

docna.cdata!:
Latvia - Solid Waste Management and Landfill
            Gas Recovery Project

Latvia - Solid Waste Management

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Municipal Solid Waste Management
            Project : Getlini waste disposal site remediation and
            upgrading environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
One of the objectives of the Municipal
            Solid Waste Management Project is to remediate environmental
            pollution and modernize the Getlini landfill site to
            international good practice standards.  The purpose of this
            environmental assessment is to identify the potential
            environmental impacts which may result from the proposed
            remediation and extension of the existing Getlini landfill
            site, to assess their significance and to identify
            mitigation measures.  Leachate, which is produced directly
            from liquid waste and refuse moisture content, will be
            arrested, collected, and treated.  Surface runoff from waste
            pile, which is a source of water pollution, will be directed
            to surface ditches and treated prior to discharge to the
            Daugava.  A study of water quality, pollutant loadings, and
            hydrodynamics will be conducted to minimize the potential of
            adverse impacts on water quality in the Daugava.  Road
            maintenance and regular sweeping can minimize dust emissions
            from landfill operation.  Noise generated from construction
            and operation of the landfill site will be monitored, and a
            noise action plan will be prepared.  Air quality impacts
            from waste haulage vehicles can be mitigated by proper
            maintenance of the vehicles.

            Project : Getlini waste disposal site remediation and
            upgrading environmental assessment
